moves.1. Nf3: definitely an opening I'm not used to
moves.1... Nf6: my option goes to the most common answer to Nf3
moves.2. Nc3: most common are c4, g3 or d4.
moves.2... d5 3. e3 e6: allowing the B to come to play
moves.4... Nc6: in this phase I'm putting pieces to play
moves.7. b4:
according to the game analysis this was a mistake.
next moves would be:
7. b4 a5 8. b5 Ne5 9. Bd2 Bd7 10. a4 Neg4 11. h3 Ne5 12. Rb1 Qe7 13. g4 Nxf3+ 14. Qxf3 Be5
moves.7... a6 8. e4 dxe4: e5 was a threat. between retiring the B or the N or reinforcing the defense of e5, I preferred  taking the pawn
moves.9. dxe4 Ne5: putting pressure on the N and opening the d rank
moves.10. Bb2 Bd7: in here my idea was to limit the action of the N while moving the B to the battlefield
moves.11. Nxe5 Bxe5 12. g3 Bb5:
funny situation.
putting pressure on the Q knowing that the N could take the B.
if the Q moves away I was thinking about exchanging B's with the idea of making castle on the ideal side impossible.
moves.13... Bxb2 14. Rb1 Be5: moving away with the B while keeping the pressure on Nb5
moves.15. Rd1:
the natural attack from white.
This is the moment I decide a crazy attack

game analysis tells me that the way to go would be: … Qe8 16. f4 Bxf4 17. gxf4 axb5 18. Qxb5 Qxb5 19. Bxb5 Rxa3 20. O-O Nxe4 21. Rd7 Nc3 22. Bc4 b5 23. Bd3
moves.15... axb5:
sacrificing the Q

the idea with this ladder games is to be bold on the approach to the game. 

In Team games and Tournaments I would never would try this
moves.16. Rxd8 Bc3+ 17. Kd1: White's big error. Rd2 would level things up
moves.17... Rfxd8+: from now on things are lost for white
moves.18. Kc1 Rxa3: ... and I was happy with it!
